Diam-diam, Malaysia Incar Proyek Ibu Kota Baru di Kaltim
06 Nov 2019, 16:00 by Tim detikcom


Desain ibu kota baru di Kalimantan/Foto: Kementerian PUPR

Jakarta - Pemerintah mulai ancang-ancang membangun ibu kota baru di Kalimantan Timur. Dua wilayah sudah dipilih Presiden Joko Widodo yaitu Penajam Paser Utara dan Kutai Kartanegara.Para investor asing pun mulai melirik rencana pemerintah membangun ibu kota baru. Salah satunya dari Malaysia"Investor yang berinisiatif tapi mereka nggak bicara secara spesifik. Jadi mereka mau berpartisipasi untuk semua sektor misal SDA (Sumber Daya Air), untuk jalan, untuk cipta karya, Ada beberapa [investor asing], yang pasti negara tetangga kita masuk, Malaysia," tutur Direktur Jenderal Pembiayaan Infrastruktur Kementerian PUPR Eko Djoeli Heripoerwanto di JIExpo Kemayoran, Jakarta, Rabu (6/11/2019).Menurut Eko Malaysia tertarik membangun infrastruktur sumber daya air. Meski tak mengungkap identitas investor tersebut, Eko memastikan investor asal Negeri Jiran itu punya pengalaman di bidang sumber daya air.Keterlibatan investor, termasuk asing, memang dibuka karena pemerintah menggenjot investasi swasta di ibu kota baru. Langkah ini juga untuk menyiasati terbatasnya dana pada APBN."Kalau di sektor PUPR hampir semua ditawarkan yang ibu kota. Baik jalan non-tol, tol, perumahan, building juga akan menjadi tanggung jawab kita itu semuanya nanti akan ditawarkan karena APBN memang sedikit," terang Eko.Dia menambahkan tahapan lelang dan pembangunan ibu kota baru ini tidak jauh berbeda dengan proyek pada umumnya."IKN atau non IKN sama. Pertama itu adalah perencanaan, kemudian penyiapan, seksi, dan konstruksi. Tahapnnya seperti itu," katanya.Sebagai informasi, Kementerian PUPR memaparkan sejumlah infrastruktur dasar yang akan dibangun di ibu kota baru negara Republik Indonesia yang rencananya dibangun di Kalimantan Timur. Infrastruktur tersebut di mencakup kebutuhan air dasar, jalan, jembatan, jalur kereta hingga jalur sepeda dan pemukiman.Untuk sektor jalan dan jembatan akan dibangun jalan tol lingkar sepanjang 57 km untuk sekitar 4.000 Ha wilayah ibu kota. Kemudian ada pula jalan non tol nasional 71 km di kawasan inti pusat pemerintahan, 629 km jalan di kawasan ibu kota negara, dan 198 km jalan di perbatasan ibu kota atau perluasan ibu kota.Untuk kebutuhan air dasar dengan asumsi jumlah penduduk 2 juta orang, diperlukan ketersediaan air baku dengan kapasitas 6,9 m3/detik untuk mencukupi kebutuhan 300 liter/hari/orang. Kemudian diperlukan juga manajemen banjir, drainase, serta infrastruktur energi seperti PLTA dan gas.Artikel asli berita ini dapat dilihat pada CNBC Indonesia berjudul Malaysia Mulai Curi-Curi Pandang, Incar Proyek Ibu Kota Baru Simak Video "Dear Pemerintah, Waspadai Isu Lingkungan yang Bisa Muncul di Ibu Kota Baru"[Gambas:Video 20detik](hns/dna)

Secretly, Malaysia is eyeing the New Capital Project in East Kalimantan
Nov 6 2019, 16:00 by Tim detikcom


Design of a new capital city in Kalimantan / Photo: Ministry of PUPR

Jakarta - The government is starting to start developing a new capital city in East Kalimantan. Two regions have been chosen by President Joko Widodo, North Penajam Paser and Kutai Kartanegara. Foreign investors have begun to look at the government's plan to build a new capital city. One of them is from Malaysia "Investors who took the initiative but they did not speak specifically. So they want to participate in all sectors, for example SDA (Water Resources), for the road, to create works, there are some [foreign investors], our neighboring countries will definitely , Malaysia, "said the Director General of Infrastructure Financing at the Ministry of PUPR Eko Djoeli Heripoerwanto at JIExpo Kemayoran, Jakarta, Wednesday (6/11/2019). According to Eko Malaysia was interested in building water resources infrastructure. Although Eko did not reveal the identity of the investor, the investor from the neighbor country had experience in the field of water resources. The involvement of investors, including foreigners, was indeed opened because the government encouraged private investment in the new capital. This step is also to get around the limited funds in the state budget. "If in the PUPR sector almost all are offered by the capital. Both non-toll roads, toll roads, housing, buildings will also be our responsibility, all of which will later be offered because the state budget is indeed small," He added that the stages of the auction and construction of the new capital city were not much different from the projects in general. "IKN or non-IKN are the same. First it is planning, then preparation, section, and construction. The stage is like that," he said. The Ministry of PUPR explained a number of basic infrastructure that will be built in the new capital city of the Republic of Indonesia which is planned to be built in East Kalimantan. The infrastructure includes basic water needs, roads, bridges, railroad tracks to bicycle lanes and settlements. For the road and bridge sector a 57 km of toll roads will be built for around 4,000 Ha of the capital region. Then there are also 71 km of national non-toll roads in the core area of the central government, 629 km of roads in the national capital region, and 198 km of roads on the border of the capital or expansion of the capital. For basic water needs assuming a population of 2 million, availability of raw water with a capacity of 6.9 m3 / second to meet the needs of 300 liters / day / person. Then also needed flood management, drainage, and energy infrastructure such as hydropower and gas. The original article of this news can be seen on CNBC Indonesia titled Malaysia Starts a Steal of Watch, Aiming for New Capital Projects in the New Capital City "[Gambas: 20sec video] (hns / dna)
